question: Pallidothalamic axons cross the <image 1>
options: ['Anterior limb of the internal capsule.', 'Genu of the internal capsule.', 'Posterior limb of the internal capsule.']
description:
The image shows a coronal section of the brain, specifically highlighting the internal capsule region. The internal capsule is divided into three parts: the anterior limb, genu, and posterior limb. In this particular view, the posterior limb of the internal capsule is prominently visible. It appears as a thick band of white matter located between the thalamus (superiorly) and the cerebral peduncles (inferiorly). The pallidothalamic axons, which connect the globus pallidus to the thalamus, are seen crossing through this posterior limb. The anterior limb and genu of the internal capsule are also present but are not as prominent in this section. The surrounding structures include the thalamus, lentiform nucleus, and other subcortical regions. The image clearly demonstrates the anatomical location where the pallidothalamic axons traverse. 

Based on this description, the correct answer to the question is:

C. Posterior limb of the internal capsule.
